\useosf

Geometric and spectral properties of causal maps

Nicolas Curien, Tom Hutchcroft, and Asaf Nachmias
Abstract

We study the random planar map obtained from a critical, finite variance, Galton-Watson plane tree by adding the horizontal connections between successive vertices at each level. This random graph is closely related to the well-known causal dynamical triangulation that was introduced by Ambjørn and Loll and has been studied extensively by physicists. We prove that the horizontal distances in the graph are smaller than the vertical distances, but only by a subpolynomial factor: The diameter of the set of vertices at level n𝑛n is both o​(n)𝑜𝑛o(n) and n1−o​(1)superscript𝑛1𝑜1n^{1-o(1)}. This enables us to prove that the spectral dimension of the infinite version of the graph is almost surely equal to 2, and consequently that the random walk is diffusive almost surely. We also initiate an investigation of the case in which the offspring distribution is critical and belongs to the domain of attraction of an α𝛼\alpha-stable law for α∈(1,2)𝛼12\alpha\in(1,2), for which our understanding is much less complete.

1 Introduction

The causal dynamical triangulation (CDT) was introduced by theoretical physicists Jan Ambjørn and Renate Loll as a discrete model of Lorentzian quantum gravity in which space and time play different roles [7]. Time is represented by a partition of the d+1𝑑1d+1-dimensional model into a sequence of d𝑑d-dimensional layers with increasing distances from the origin. Although this model has been the subject of extensive numerical investigation [5, 6], especially in dimension 2+1212+1 and 3+1313+1, very little is known analytically, let alone rigorously.

In the case of dimension 1+1111+1, the 111-dimensional layers are simply cycles, and causal triangulations are in bijection with plane trees, see e.g. [17, 32]. Figure 2 below illustrates the mechanism used to build a causal triangulation from a plane tree τ𝜏\tau: We first add the horizontal connections between successive vertices in each layer to obtain a planar map 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) living on the sphere, and then triangulate the non-triangular faces of this map as shown in the drawing to obtain the triangulation 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀𝜏\mathsf{CauTrig}(\tau). See Section 5.1 and [17, Section 2.3] or [32, Section 2.2] for more details.

The maps 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) and 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀𝜏\mathsf{CauTrig}(\tau) are qualitatively very similar. We shall focus in this article on the model 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) (mainly to simplify our drawings) and refer the reader to Section 5.1 for extensions of our results to other models including causal triangulations.

The geometry of large random plane trees is by now very well understood [2, 9, 15]. However, we shall see that causal maps have geometric and spectral properties that are dramatically different to the plane trees used to construct them. Indeed, the causal maps have much more in common with uniform random planar maps [27] such as the UIPT than they do with random trees.

Setup and results.

Suppose that τ𝜏\tau is a finite plane tree. We can associate with it a finite planar map (graph) denoted by 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) by adding the ‘horizontal’ edges linking successive vertices in the cyclical ordering of each level of the tree as in Figure 2. If τ𝜏\tau is an infinite, locally finite plane tree, performing the same operation yields an infinite planar map with one end, see Figure 1. The distance between a vertex v𝑣v of τ𝜏\tau and the root ρ𝜌\rho, called the height of v𝑣v, is clearly equal in the two graphs τ𝜏\tau and 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau). Thus, a natural first question is to understand how the distances between pairs of vertices at the same height are affected by the addition of the horizontal edges in the causal graph. We formalize this as follows: Let τ𝜏\tau be a plane tree with root ρ𝜌\rho. Let [τ]ksubscriptdelimited-[]𝜏𝑘[\tau]_{k} be the subtree spanned by the vertices of height at most k𝑘k and let ∂[τ]ksubscriptdelimited-[]𝜏𝑘\partial[\tau]_{k} be the set of vertices of height exactly k𝑘k. We define the girth at height r𝑟r of 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) to be

𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)):=sup{dgr𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)​(x,y):x,y∈∂[τ]r}, where ​sup∅=0,formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁𝑟𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏supremumconditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptdgr𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏𝑥𝑦𝑥𝑦subscriptdelimited-[]𝜏𝑟 where supremum0\mathsf{Girth}_{r}\bigl{(}\mathsf{Causal}(\tau)\bigr{)}:=\sup\left\{\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{gr}}^{\mathsf{Causal}(\tau)}(x,y):x,y\in\partial[\tau]_{r}\right\},\quad\mbox{ where }\sup\varnothing=0,

and where dgrGsuperscriptsubscriptdgr𝐺\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{gr}}^{G} denotes the graph distance in the graph G𝐺G. The triangle inequality yields the trivial bound 𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ))≤2​rsubscript𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁𝑟𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏2𝑟\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathsf{Causal}(\tau))\leq 2r, so that the girth grows at most linearly.

We will focus first on the case that the underlying tree τ𝜏\tau is a random Galton-Watson tree whose offspring distribution μ𝜇\mu is critical (i.e., has mean 111) and has finite variance 0<σ2<∞0superscript𝜎20<\sigma^{2}<\infty. The classical CDT model is related to the special case in which μ𝜇\mu is a mean 111 geometric distribution. Let T𝑇T be a μ𝜇\mu-Galton-Watson tree (which is almost surely finite) and let T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} be a μ𝜇\mu-Galton-Watson tree conditioned to survive forever [1, 23]. Let 𝒞∞=𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)subscript𝒞𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathscr{C}_{\infty}=\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}). It is well-known that #​∂[T∞]r≈r#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑟𝑟\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}\approx r under the above hypotheses on μ𝜇\mu. Our first main result states that the addition of the horizontal edges to the causal graph makes the girth at height r𝑟r smaller, but only by a subpolynomial factor.

Theorem 1 (Geometry of generic causal maps).

Let μ𝜇\mu be critical and have finite non-zero variance. Then

(i)log⁡𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)log⁡r→r→∞(a.s.)1 and (i​i)𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)r→r→∞(ℙ)0.(i)\quad\frac{\log\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})}{\log r}\xrightarrow[r\to\infty]{(a.s.)}1\quad\mbox{ and }\quad(ii)\quad\frac{\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})}{r}\xrightarrow[r\to\infty]{(\mathbb{P})}0.

A corollary of item (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) of Theorem 1 is that every geodesic between any two points at height r𝑟r in 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} stays within a strip of vertices at height r±o​(r)plus-or-minus𝑟𝑜𝑟r\pm o(r) with high probability. This in turn implies that the scaling limit of r−1⋅𝒞∞⋅superscript𝑟1subscript𝒞r^{-1}\cdot\mathscr{C}_{\infty} (in the local Gromov–Hausdorff sense) is just a single semi-infinite line (ℝ+,|⋅|)(\mathbb{R}_{+},|\cdot|). In other words, the metric in the horizontal (space) direction is collapsed relative to the metric in the vertical (time) direction, leading to a degenerate scaling limit.

The proof of item (i)𝑖(i) is based on a block-renormalisation argument and also yields the quantitative result that 𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)≥r​e−O​(log⁡r)subscript𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁𝑟subscript𝒞𝑟superscript𝑒𝑂𝑟\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\geq re^{-O(\sqrt{\log r})} as r→∞→𝑟r\to\infty almost surely (Proposition 3). On the other hand, item (i​i)𝑖𝑖(ii) uses the subadditive ergodic theorem and is not quantitative.

Once the geometry of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} is fairly well understood, we can apply this geometric understanding to study its spectral properties. We first show that 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} is almost surely recurrent (Proposition 4) generalizing the result of [17]. Next, we apply Theorem 1 to prove the following results, the first of which completes the work of [17]. Given a connected graph G𝐺G and a vertex x𝑥x, we denote by 𝐏G,xsubscript𝐏𝐺𝑥\mathbf{P}_{G,x} the law of the simple random walk (Xn)n≥0subscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑛0(X_{n})_{n\geq 0} started at x𝑥x and denote by PGt​(x,x)superscriptsubscript𝑃𝐺𝑡𝑥𝑥P_{G}^{t}(x,x) the t𝑡t-step return probability to x𝑥x. The spectral dimension dssubscript𝑑𝑠d_{s} of a connected graph G𝐺G is defined to be

ds​(G)=limn→∞−2​log⁡PG2​n​(x,x)log⁡nsubscript𝑑𝑠𝐺subscript→𝑛2superscriptsubscript𝑃𝐺2𝑛𝑥𝑥𝑛d_{s}(G)=\lim_{n\to\infty}-\frac{2\log P_{G}^{2n}(x,x)}{\log n}

should this limit exist (in which case it does not depend on x𝑥x). We also define the typical displacement exponent ν=ν​(G)𝜈𝜈𝐺\nu=\nu(G) of the connected graph G𝐺G by

limn→∞𝐏G,x​(nν−ε≤dgrG​(x,Xn)≤nν+ε)=1​ for every ε>0subscript→𝑛subscript𝐏𝐺𝑥superscript𝑛𝜈𝜀superscriptsubscriptdgr𝐺𝑥subscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑛𝜈𝜀1 for every ε>0\lim_{n\to\infty}\mathbf{P}_{G,x}\bigl{(}n^{\nu-\varepsilon}\leq\mathrm{d}_{\mathrm{gr}}^{G}(x,X_{n})\leq n^{\nu+\varepsilon}\bigr{)}=1\text{ for every $\varepsilon>0$}

should such an exponent exist (in which case it is clearly unique and does not depend on x𝑥x). We say that G𝐺G is diffusive for simple random walk if the typical displacement exponent ν​(G)𝜈𝐺\nu(G) exists and equals 1/2121/2.

Theorem 2 (Spectral dimension and diffusivity of generic causal maps).

Let μ𝜇\mu be critical with finite non-zero variance. Then

ds​(𝒞∞)=2 and ν​(𝒞∞)=1/2formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑠subscript𝒞2 and 𝜈subscript𝒞12d_{s}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})=2\quad\text{ and }\quad\nu(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})=1/2

almost surely. In particular, both exponents exist almost surely.

Note that these exponents are not the same as the underlying tree T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty}, which has ds=4/3subscript𝑑𝑠43d_{s}=4/3 and ν=1/3𝜈13\nu=1/3 [9, 16, 18, 23].

The central step in the proof of Theorem 2 is to prove that the exponent 𝔯𝔯\mathfrak{r} governing the growth of the resistance between ρ𝜌\rho and the boundary of the ball of radius n𝑛n in 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}, defined by 𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔∂[T∞]n;𝒞∞)=n𝔯+o​(1)\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n};\,\mathscr{C}_{\infty})=n^{\mathfrak{r}+o(1)}, is 𝔯=0𝔯0\mathfrak{r}=0. In fact, we prove the following quantitative subpolynomial upper bound on the resistance growth. This estimate is established using geometric controls on 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} and the method of random paths [30, Chapter 2.5]. It had previously been open to prove any sublinear upper bound on the resistance.

Theorem 3 (Resistance bound for generic causal maps ).

Suppose μ𝜇\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance. Then there exists a constant C𝐶C such that almost surely for all r𝑟r sufficiently large we have

𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔∂[T∞]r;𝒞∞)≤eC​log⁡r.\mathsf{{R}_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r};\,\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\leq e^{C\sqrt{\log r}}.

Theorem 2 can easily be deduced from Theorem 3 by abstract considerations. Indeed, by classical properties of Galton–Watson trees, the volume growth exponent 𝔤𝔤\mathfrak{g}, defined by #​Ball​(ρ,n)=n𝔤+o​(1)#Ball𝜌𝑛superscript𝑛𝔤𝑜1\#\mathrm{Ball}(\rho,n)=n^{\mathfrak{g}+o(1)}, is easily seen to be equal to 222. For recurrent graphs, the spectral dimension and typical displacement exponent can typically be computed from the volume growth and resistance growth exponents via the formulas

ds=2​𝔤𝔤+𝔯, and ds=2​ν​𝔤,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑠2𝔤𝔤𝔯 and subscript𝑑𝑠2𝜈𝔤d_{s}=\frac{2\mathfrak{g}}{\mathfrak{g}+\mathfrak{r}},\qquad\text{ and }\qquad d_{s}=2\nu\mathfrak{g},

which yield ds=2subscript𝑑𝑠2d_{s}=2 and ν=1/𝔤𝜈1𝔤\nu=1/\mathfrak{g} whenever 𝔯=0𝔯0\mathfrak{r}=0. Although this relationship between exponents holds rather generally (see [8, 25, 26]), things become substantially simpler in our case of 𝔯=0,𝔯0\mathfrak{r}=0, 𝔤=2𝔤2\mathfrak{g}=2 and we include a direct derivation. Indeed, in this case it suffices to use the inequalities

ds≥2−2​𝔯,ds≤2​ν​𝔤, and 𝔤<∞⇒ν≤1/2,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑠22𝔯formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑠2𝜈𝔤 and 𝔤⇒𝜈12d_{s}\geq 2-2\mathfrak{r},\quad d_{s}\leq 2\nu\mathfrak{g},\quad\text{ and }\quad\mathfrak{g}<\infty\Rightarrow\nu\leq 1/2,

which are more easily proven and require weaker controls on the graph. Let us note in particular that the upper bounds on dssubscript𝑑𝑠d_{s} and ν𝜈\nu are easy consequences of the Varopoulos-Carne bound and do not require the full machinery of this paper.

1.1 The α𝛼\alpha-stable case.

Besides the finite variance case, we also study the case in which the offspring distribution μ𝜇\mu is critical and is “α𝛼\alpha-stable” in the sense that it satisfies the asymptotic111Here f​(k)∼g​(k)similar-to𝑓𝑘𝑔𝑘f(k)\sim g(k) means that f​(k)/g​(k)→1→𝑓𝑘𝑔𝑘1f(k)/g(k)\to 1 as k→+∞→𝑘k\to+\infty.

μ​([k,∞))∼k→∞c​k−α, for some ​c>0​ and ​α∈(1,2).𝜇𝑘→𝑘similar-to𝑐superscript𝑘𝛼 for some 𝑐0 and 𝛼12\displaystyle\mu([k,\infty))\quad\underset{k\to\infty}{\sim}\quad c\ k^{-\alpha},\quad\mbox{ for some }c>0\mbox{ and }\alpha\in(1,2). (1)

In particular the law μ𝜇\mu is in the strict domain of attraction of the totally asymmetric α𝛼\alpha-stable distribution (we restrict here to polynomially decaying tails to avoid technical complications involving slowing varying functions). The study of such causal maps is motivated by their connection to uniform random planar triangulations. Indeed, Krikun’s skeleton decomposition [24] identifies an object related to the stable causal map with exponent α=32𝛼32\alpha=\frac{3}{2} inside the UIPT, see Section 5.2.

We still denote by T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} the μ𝜇\mu-Galton–Watson tree conditioned to be infinite (the dependence in μ𝜇\mu, and hence in α𝛼\alpha, is implicit), and denote by 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} the associated causal map. The geometry of μ𝜇\mu-Galton–Watson trees with critical “α𝛼\alpha-stable” offspring distribution is known to be drastically different from the finite variance case. In particular, the size of the n𝑛nth generation of T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} is of order n1α−1superscript𝑛1𝛼1n^{\frac{1}{\alpha-1}} rather than n𝑛n, and the the scaling limit is given by the (infinite) stable tree of Duquesne, Le Gall and Le Jan [15], rather than the Brownian tree of Aldous [2].

We prove that there is a further pronounced difference occuring when one investigates the associated causal maps. Namely, while the girth at height r𝑟r was strictly sublinear in the finite variance case, it is linear in the α𝛼\alpha-stable case. In particular, we have the following analog of Theorem 1.

Theorem 4 (Geometry of stable causal maps).

If μ𝜇\mu is critical and satisfies (1) then we have

(i)log⁡𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)log⁡r→r→∞(a.s.)1 and (i​i)limε→0infr≥1ℙ​(𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)≥ε​r)=1.(i)\quad\frac{\log\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})}{\log r}\xrightarrow[r\to\infty]{(a.s.)}1\quad\mbox{ and }\quad(ii)\quad\lim_{\varepsilon\to 0}\inf_{r\geq 1}\mathbb{P}\left(\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\geq\varepsilon r\right)=1.

Similar to Theorem 1, the proof of this theorem uses a block-renormalisation argument. We conjecture that in fact r−1​𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)superscript𝑟1subscript𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁𝑟subscript𝒞r^{-1}\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty}) converges in distribution and more generally that r−1⋅𝒞∞⋅superscript𝑟1subscript𝒞r^{-1}\cdot\mathscr{C}_{\infty} converges in the local Gromov–Hausdorff sense. These questions will be addressed in a forthcoming work of the first author. This theorem (and its proof) in fact have direct consequences in the theory of uniform random planar triangulations, using Krikun’s skeleton decomposition; see Section 5 for further details.

The adaptation of the techniques used to prove Theorem 2 here yields that the resistance exponent satisfies

𝔯≤2−αα−1,𝔯2𝛼𝛼1\mathfrak{r}\leq\frac{2-\alpha}{\alpha-1}, (2)

while the volume growth exponent is known to be 𝔤=αα−1𝔤𝛼𝛼1\mathfrak{g}=\frac{\alpha}{\alpha-1} [11]. Notice that this bound is only useful in the range α∈(3/2,2)𝛼322\alpha\in(3/2,2) since we always have 𝔯≤1𝔯1\mathfrak{r}\leq 1. This witnesses that our understanding of the spectral properties of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} in the α𝛼\alpha-stable case is much less advanced than in the finite variance case. The bound (2) becomes much more interesting in the case of the α𝛼\alpha-stable causal carpet, which we expect to really have polynomial resistance growth; see Section 5.2 for further discussion. We remark that the spectral properties of the tree T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} have been studied by Croydon and Kumagai [11], who prove in particular that T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} has spectral dimension 2​α/(2​α−1)2𝛼2𝛼12\alpha/(2\alpha-1) almost surely.

We are embarrassed to leave the following question open:

Open question 1.

Suppose that μ𝜇\mu is critical and satisfies (1). Is 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} a.s. transient?

Organization.

The paper is organized as follows. In Section 2 we present the renormalisation technique that enables to bound from below the girth of causal graphs in a “quarter-plane” model carrying more independence than 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. This technique is rather general and we hope the presentation will make it easy to adapt to other settings. We also present the subadditive argument (Section 2.3) which gives the sublinear girth in the case of finite variance offspring distribution. Section 3 is then devoted to the careful proof of Theorem 1 and 4, which is done by dragging the quarter-plane estimates through to the original model 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. In Section 4, we use the geometric knowledge gathered thusfar to prove Theorem 3 and deduce Theorem 2. Section 5 is devoted to extensions and comments.

For the rest of the paper, μ𝜇\mu will be a fixed critical offspring distribution. Furthermore, we will always assume either that μ𝜇\mu has a finite, positive variance, or else that (1) holds for some α∈(1,2)𝛼12\alpha\in(1,2). We refer to these two cases as the finite variance and α𝛼\alpha-stable cases respectively. To unify notation, we let β=1𝛽1\beta=1 in the finite variance case and β=1α−1>1𝛽1𝛼11\beta=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}>1 in the α𝛼\alpha-stable case.

2 Estimates on the quarter-plane model

The goal of this section is to study the girth of random causal graphs. For this, we first define a “quarter-plane” model carrying more symmetries and independence properties than T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty}. We then define the notion of a block and establish the key renormalisation lemma than enables us to lower bound the width of a block (Proposition 1). The outcome of this renormalisation procedure is slightly different depending on whether μ𝜇\mu has finite variance or is “α𝛼\alpha-stable”. These estimates will later be transferred to the actual model 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} in Section 3. In Section 2.3 we present the subadditive argument for the quarter-plane model (Proposition 2) which will enable us to prove that the width is sublinear in the finite variance case.

Before presenting the quarter-plane model, let us start by recalling a few standard estimates on critical Galton–Watson trees. Recall that μ𝜇\mu is always a critical offspring distribution and recall the definition of β𝛽\beta above. The famous estimate of Kolmogorov and its extension to the stable case by Slack [33] states that

ℙ​(𝖧𝖾𝗂𝗀𝗁𝗍​(T)≥n)∼c​n−β,for some ​c>0, as ​n→∞.formulae-sequencesimilar-toℙ𝖧𝖾𝗂𝗀𝗁𝗍𝑇𝑛𝑐superscript𝑛𝛽formulae-sequencefor some 𝑐0→ as 𝑛\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(\mathsf{Height}(T)\geq n)\sim c\,n^{-\beta},\quad\mbox{for some }c>0,\quad\mbox{ as }n\to\infty. (3)

Furthermore, conditionally on non-extinction at generation n𝑛n, the total size of generation n𝑛n converges after rescaling by nβsuperscript𝑛𝛽n^{\beta} towards a non-zero random variable (Yaglom’s limit and its extension by Slack [33]):

(n−β#∂[T]n∈⋅∣𝖧𝖾𝗂𝗀𝗁𝗍(T)≥n)→n→∞(d)𝒳,\displaystyle\left(n^{-\beta}\#\partial[T]_{n}\in\cdot\mid\mathsf{Height}(T)\geq n\right)\xrightarrow[n\to\infty]{(d)}\mathcal{X}, (4)

where 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X} is an explicit positive random variable (but whose exact distribution will not be used in the sequel).

2.1 The block-renormalisation scheme

The quarter-plane model.

We consider a sequence T1,T2,…subscript𝑇1subscript𝑇2…T_{1},T_{2},\dots of independent and identically distributed μ𝜇\mu-Galton–Watson trees. We can then index the vertices of this forest by {1,2,…}×{0,1,…}12…01…\{1,2,\ldots\}\times\{0,1,\ldots\} in an obvious way as depicted in the Figure 3 below.

Adding the horizontals edges (i,j)↔(i+1,j)↔𝑖𝑗𝑖1𝑗(i,j)\leftrightarrow(i+1,j) forms an infinite planar map (graph) which we call the quarter-plane model and denote by 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty}. Let ξr≥1subscript𝜉𝑟1\xi_{r}\geq 1 be minimal such that Tξrsubscript𝑇subscript𝜉𝑟T_{\xi_{r}} reaches height r𝑟r. The block of height r𝑟r, denoted 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, is defined to be the subgraph of 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty} induced by the vertices of T1,…,Tξrsubscript𝑇1…subscript𝑇subscript𝜉𝑟T_{1},\dots,T_{\xi_{r}} at height less than or equal to r𝑟r. That is, 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} consists of all the vertices of T1,…,Tξrsubscript𝑇1…subscript𝑇subscript𝜉𝑟T_{1},\dots,T_{\xi_{r}} at height less than or equal to r𝑟r and all the edges of 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty} (both horizontal and vertical) between them. See Fig. 3 for an illustration. Clearly, we can speak of the two sets of vertices belonging respectively to the left side and right side of the block 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, that is, the set of r+1𝑟1r+1 left most vertices and the set of r+1𝑟1r+1 right most vertices of the block. We define the width of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, denoted by 𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢r)𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝑟\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r}), to be the minimal graph distance (in 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}) between a vertex in the left side and a vertex in the right side of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, see Fig. 3. The width of a block is not uniformly large when r𝑟r is large: Indeed, the first tree T1subscript𝑇1T_{1} may actually reach the level r𝑟r in which case 𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢r)=0𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝑟0\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r})=0. However, we will see that a large block typically has a large width. To this end, we consider the median of 𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢r)𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝑟\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r}):

Definition 1.

For each r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1 let f​(r)𝑓𝑟f(r) be the median width of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, that is, the largest number such that

ℙ​(𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢r)≥f​(r))≥1/2.ℙ𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝑟𝑓𝑟12\mathbb{P}\big{(}\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r})\geq f(r)\big{)}\geq 1/2.

As usual, the dependence on the offspring distribution is implicit in the notation. Obviously the value 1/2121/2 is not special. Note that, depending on μ𝜇\mu, one might have that f​(r)=0𝑓𝑟0f(r)=0 for small values of r𝑟r. On the other hand, 𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢𝓇)𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝓇\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G_{r}}) is bounded deterministically by 2​r2𝑟2r since all vertices in the top layer of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} share a common ancestor in level zero, so that f​(r)≤2​r𝑓𝑟2𝑟f(r)\leq 2r also. Our main technical result shows that f​(r)𝑓𝑟f(r) is always roughly linear, more precisely:

Theorem 5 (f​(r)𝑓𝑟f(r) is almost linear).

If μ𝜇\mu is critical and satisfies (1) then there exists c>0𝑐0c>0 such that

f​(r)≥c​r𝑓𝑟𝑐𝑟f(r)\geq c\,r (5)

for all r𝑟r sufficiently large. On the other hand, if μ𝜇\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance then there exists C>0𝐶0C>0 such that

f​(r)≥r​exp⁡(−C​log⁡r)𝑓𝑟𝑟𝐶𝑟f(r)\geq r\exp(-C\sqrt{\log r}) (6)

for all r𝑟r sufficiently large.

The above theorem is an analytic consequence of the following proposition which encapsulates the renormalisation scheme. Recall the definition of β≥1𝛽1\beta\geq 1 at the end of the Introduction.

Proposition 1.

There exists c>0𝑐0c>0 such that for any 1≤m≤c⋅r1𝑚⋅𝑐𝑟1\leq m\leq c\cdot r we have

f​(r)≥c⋅min⁡{m;(r/m)β​f​(m)}.𝑓𝑟⋅𝑐𝑚superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽𝑓𝑚f(r)\geq c\cdot\min\Big{\{}m;\,(r/m)^{\beta}f(m)\Big{\}}. (7)

The proof of this proposition relies on a renormalisation scheme in which 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} is split into smaller blocks distributed as 𝒢msubscript𝒢𝑚\mathcal{G}_{m} for 0≤m≤r0𝑚𝑟0\leq m\leq r. Before starting the proof, let us introduce some notation. Let m,h≥0𝑚ℎ0m,h\geq 0, and consider the layer of thickness m𝑚m between heights hℎh and h+mℎ𝑚h+m in the quarter-plane model 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty}. This layer is composed of a sequence of blocks of height m𝑚m which we denote by 𝒢m​(i,h)subscript𝒢𝑚𝑖ℎ\mathcal{G}_{m}(i,h) for i≥1𝑖1i\geq 1. For any fixed m,h≥0𝑚ℎ0m,h\geq 0, these blocks are of course independent and distributed as 𝒢msubscript𝒢𝑚\mathcal{G}_{m} (indeed, 𝒢m​(1,0)subscript𝒢𝑚10\mathcal{G}_{m}(1,0) is equal to 𝒢msubscript𝒢𝑚\mathcal{G}_{m}). When h+m≤rℎ𝑚𝑟h+m\leq r, we denote by Nr​(m,h)subscript𝑁𝑟𝑚ℎN_{r}(m,h) the maximal i𝑖i such that the block 𝒢m​(i,h)subscript𝒢𝑚𝑖ℎ\mathcal{G}_{m}(i,h) is a subblock of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}.

We also recall the following classical Chernoff-type bound for sums of indicator random variables [4, Corollary A.1.14], which will be used throughout the paper: For every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 there exists a constant cε>0subscript𝑐𝜀0c_{\varepsilon}>0 such that for every k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1 and every sequence X1,…​Xksubscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑘X_{1},\ldots X_{k} of mutually independent {0,1}01\{0,1\}-valued random variables, the sum Y=∑i=1kXi𝑌superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘subscript𝑋𝑖Y=\sum_{i=1}^{k}X_{i} satisfies the bound

ℙ​(|Y−𝔼​[Y]|≥ε​𝔼​[Y])≤2​e−cε​𝔼​[Y].ℙ𝑌𝔼delimited-[]𝑌𝜀𝔼delimited-[]𝑌2superscript𝑒subscript𝑐𝜀𝔼delimited-[]𝑌\mathbb{P}\Bigl{(}\bigl{|}Y-\mathbb{E}[Y]\bigr{|}\geq\varepsilon\,\mathbb{E}[Y]\Bigr{)}\leq 2e^{-c_{\varepsilon}\mathbb{E}[Y]}. (8)

We are now ready to proceed with the proof of Proposition 1.

Proof of Proposition 1.

We will prove that there exists c>0𝑐0c>0 such that

f​(r)≥c⋅min⁡{m;(r/m)β​f​(2​m)}.𝑓𝑟⋅𝑐𝑚superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽𝑓2𝑚f(r)\geq c\cdot\min\Big{\{}m;\,(r/m)^{\beta}f(2m)\Big{\}}. (9)

for every 1≤m≤c⋅r1𝑚⋅𝑐𝑟1\leq m\leq c\cdot r that divides r𝑟r. The full proof of the claim as originally stated (in which m𝑚m replaces 2​m2𝑚2m and m𝑚m is not assumed to divide r𝑟r) is very similar but requires messier notation.

We bound from below the width of the block 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} using the widths of the blocks 𝒢2​m​(i,h)subscript𝒢2𝑚𝑖ℎ\mathcal{G}_{2m}(i,h) for hℎh of the form ℓ⋅m⋅ℓ𝑚\ell\cdot m with 0≤ℓ≤(r/m)−20ℓ𝑟𝑚20\leq\ell\leq(r/m)-2. Suppose that we pick a point x𝑥x on the left side of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, say at height 0≤j≤r0𝑗𝑟0\leq j\leq r. If m/3≤j≤r−m/3𝑚3𝑗𝑟𝑚3m/3\leq j\leq r-m/3 then we can clearly take 0≤ℓ≤(r/m)−20ℓ𝑟𝑚20\leq\ell\leq(r/m)-2 such that |ℓ​m−j|≥m/3ℓ𝑚𝑗𝑚3|\ell m-j|\geq m/3 and |(ℓ+2)​m−j|≥m/3ℓ2𝑚𝑗𝑚3|(\ell+2)m-j|\geq m/3. Otherwise, we either have that 0≤j<m/30𝑗𝑚30\leq j<m/3 and take ℓ=0ℓ0\ell=0 or we have that r−m/3<j≤r𝑟𝑚3𝑗𝑟r-m/3<j\leq r and take ℓ=(r/m)−2ℓ𝑟𝑚2\ell=(r/m)-2. We then have an alternative: either the shortest path from x𝑥x to the other side of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} stays in the layer between heights ℓ​mℓ𝑚\ell m and (ℓ+2)​mℓ2𝑚(\ell+2)m, or else it leaves it at some point. In the second case we know that the length of the path is at least m/3𝑚3m/3 by our assumption on j𝑗j and ℓℓ\ell and since the graph distance between any two points in the graph is at least their height difference. On the other hand, in the first case, the length of such a path is at least

∑i=1Nr​(2​m,ℓ​m)𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢2​m​(i,ℓ​m)).superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℓ𝑚𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢2𝑚𝑖ℓ𝑚\sum_{i=1}^{N_{r}(2m,\ell m)}\mathsf{Width}\big{(}\mathcal{G}_{2m}(i,\ell m)\big{)}.

This is because the path must cross, from left to right, every subblock of height 2​m2𝑚2m that is in that layer and that belongs to the block 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}. See Fig. 5. We conclude that

𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢r)≥min⁡{m3,min0≤ℓ≤(r/m)−2​∑i=1Nr​(2​m,ℓ​m)𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢2​m​(i,ℓ​m))}.𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝑟𝑚3subscript0ℓ𝑟𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℓ𝑚𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢2𝑚𝑖ℓ𝑚\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r})\geq\min\Big{\{}{m\over 3},\min_{0\leq\ell\leq(r/m)-2}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{r}(2m,\ell m)}\mathsf{Width}\big{(}\mathcal{G}_{2m}(i,\ell m)\big{)}\Big{\}}\,. (10)

For fixed h,m≥1ℎ𝑚1h,m\geq 1 the blocks 𝒢2​m​(i,h)subscript𝒢2𝑚𝑖ℎ\mathcal{G}_{2m}(i,h) are independent and distributed as 𝒢2​msubscript𝒢2𝑚\mathcal{G}_{2m}. Thus, by the definition of the function f​(2​m)𝑓2𝑚f(2m) and (8), we have that

ℙ​(∑i=1k𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢2​m​(i,h))≤k⋅f​(2​m)4)≤ℙ​(Binomial​(k,1/2)≤k/4)≤e−η​kℙsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢2𝑚𝑖ℎ⋅𝑘𝑓2𝑚4ℙBinomial𝑘12𝑘4superscript𝑒𝜂𝑘\mathbb{P}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{2m}(i,h))\leq\frac{k\cdot f(2m)}{4}\right)\leq\mathbb{P}\Big{(}\mathrm{Binomial}(k,1/2)\leq k/4\Big{)}\leq e^{-\eta k}

for every k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1, where η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is a constant independent of k,h𝑘ℎk,h and m𝑚m. Summing-up over all possibilities for h=ℓ⋅mℎ⋅ℓ𝑚h=\ell\cdot m with ℓ∈{0,…,(r/m)−2}ℓ0…𝑟𝑚2\ell\in\{0,\ldots,(r/m)-2\} we deduce that with probability at least 1−rm​e−η​k1𝑟𝑚superscript𝑒𝜂𝑘1-\frac{r}{m}e^{-\eta k} we have

∀0≤ℓ≤(r/m)−2,∑i=1k𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢2​m​(i,ℓ​m))≥k⋅f​(2​m)4.formulae-sequencefor-all0ℓ𝑟𝑚2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑘𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢2𝑚𝑖ℓ𝑚⋅𝑘𝑓2𝑚4\displaystyle\forall 0\leq\ell\leq(r/m)-2,\quad\quad\sum_{i=1}^{k}\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{2m}(i,\ell m))\geq\frac{k\cdot f(2m)}{4}. (11)

We now estimate Nr​(2​m,ℓ​m)subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℓ𝑚N_{r}(2m,\ell m):

Lemma 1.

There exists c>0𝑐0c>0 such that for every 1≤m≤c​r1𝑚𝑐𝑟1\leq m\leq cr we have

ℙ​(min0≤ℓ≤(r/m)−2⁡Nr​(2​m,ℓ​m)≥c​(rm)β)≥78.ℙsubscript0ℓ𝑟𝑚2subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℓ𝑚𝑐superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽78\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{0\leq\ell\leq(r/m)-2}N_{r}(2m,\ell m)\geq c\left(\frac{r}{m}\right)^{\beta}\right)\geq\frac{7}{8}.
Proof.

We first consider the analogous estimate in the case m=0𝑚0m=0. In this case, Nr​(0,h)subscript𝑁𝑟0ℎN_{r}(0,h) is the just the number of vertices at height hℎh in the block 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}. We claim that we can find c>0𝑐0c>0 sufficiently small such that

ℙ​(min0≤h≤r⁡Nr​(0,h)≥c⋅rβ)≥15/16ℙsubscript0ℎ𝑟subscript𝑁𝑟0ℎ⋅𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽1516\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{0\leq h\leq r}N_{r}(0,h)\geq c\cdot r^{\beta}\right)\geq 15/16 (12)

for every r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. This kind of result is part of the folklore in the theory of branching processes (see e.g. [15]) but since we were not able to locate a precise reference for it we include a direct derivation at the end of this subsection (Lemma 2).

We now apply (12) to prove the claim in the statement of the lemma. Let c𝑐c be the constant from (12). Fix 0≤h≤r0ℎ𝑟0\leq h\leq r and denote by X​(h,2​m,k)𝑋ℎ2𝑚𝑘X(h,2m,k) the number of trees whose origin in the line of height hℎh has index less than k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1 and which reach height 2​m2𝑚2m relative to its starting height of hℎh. With this notation we have Nr​(2​m,h)=X​(h,2​m,Nr​(0,h))subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℎ𝑋ℎ2𝑚subscript𝑁𝑟0ℎN_{r}(2m,h)=X(h,2m,N_{r}(0,h)). For fixed k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1 the random variable X​(h,2​m,k)𝑋ℎ2𝑚𝑘X(h,2m,k) has binomial distribution with k𝑘k trials and success parameter ℙ​(Height​(T)≥2​m)ℙHeight𝑇2𝑚\mathbb{P}(\mathrm{Height}(T)\geq 2m). On the event {Nr​(0,h)≥c​rβ}∩{Nr​(2​m,h)≤c′​(r/m)β}subscript𝑁𝑟0ℎ𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℎsuperscript𝑐′superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽\{N_{r}(0,h)\geq cr^{\beta}\}\cap\{N_{r}(2m,h)\leq c^{\prime}(r/m)^{\beta}\} we have X​(h,2​m,⌈c​rβ⌉)≤c′​(r/m)β𝑋ℎ2𝑚𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽superscript𝑐′superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽X(h,2m,\lceil cr^{\beta}\rceil)\leq c^{\prime}(r/m)^{\beta}. Thus, applying (8) and (3) we deduce that there exist constants c′>0superscript𝑐′0c^{\prime}>0 and δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 such that

ℙ​(Nr​(2​m,h)≤c′​(r/m)β​ and ​Nr​(0,h)≥c⋅rβ)≤ℙ​(X​(h,2​m,⌈c​rβ⌉)≤c′​(r/m)β)≤e−δ​(r/m)βℙsubscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℎsuperscript𝑐′superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽 and subscript𝑁𝑟0ℎ⋅𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽ℙ𝑋ℎ2𝑚𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽superscript𝑐′superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽superscript𝑒𝛿superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽\mathbb{P}\Bigl{(}N_{r}(2m,h)\leq c^{\prime}(r/m)^{\beta}\mbox{ and }N_{r}(0,h)\geq c\cdot r^{\beta}\Bigr{)}\leq\mathbb{P}\Bigl{(}X(h,2m,\lceil cr^{\beta}\rceil)\leq c^{\prime}(r/m)^{\beta}\Bigr{)}\leq e^{-\delta(r/m)^{\beta}}

for every r,m,𝑟𝑚r,m, and hℎh. For sufficiently large values of r/m𝑟𝑚r/m we have that (r/m)​e−δ​(r/m)β≤1/16𝑟𝑚superscript𝑒𝛿superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽116(r/m)e^{-\delta(r/m)^{\beta}}\leq 1/16, and can proceed to apply a union bound over values of hℎh of the form ℓ​mℓ𝑚\ell m for ℓ∈{0,…,(r/m)−2}ℓ0…𝑟𝑚2\ell\in\{0,\ldots,(r/m)-2\}. Indeed, gathering up the pieces above we have that

ℙ(∃0≤ℓ≤(r/\displaystyle\mathbb{P}(\exists 0\leq\ell\leq(r/ m)−2:Nr(2m,ℓm)≤c′(r/m)β)\displaystyle m)-2:N_{r}(2m,\ell m)\leq c^{\prime}(r/m)^{\beta})
≤ℙ​(min0≤h≤r⁡Nr​(0,h)≤c⋅rβ)+∑ℓ=0(r/m)−2ℙ​(Nr​(2​m,ℓ​m)≤c′​(r/m)β,Nr​(0,ℓ​m)≥c​rβ)absentℙsubscript0ℎ𝑟subscript𝑁𝑟0ℎ⋅𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽superscriptsubscriptℓ0𝑟𝑚2ℙformulae-sequencesubscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℓ𝑚superscript𝑐′superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽subscript𝑁𝑟0ℓ𝑚𝑐superscript𝑟𝛽\displaystyle\leq\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{0\leq h\leq r}N_{r}(0,h)\leq c\cdot r^{\beta}\right)+\sum_{\ell=0}^{(r/m)-2}\mathbb{P}\left(N_{r}(2m,\ell m)\leq c^{\prime}(r/m)^{\beta},\,\,N_{r}(0,\ell m)\geq cr^{\beta}\right)
≤116+(r/m)​e−δ​(r/m)β≤116+116=18,absent116𝑟𝑚superscript𝑒𝛿superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽11611618\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{16}+(r/m)e^{-\delta(r/m)^{\beta}}\leq\frac{1}{16}+\frac{1}{16}=\frac{1}{8},

and this proves the lemma. ∎

We now return to the proof of Proposition 1. Let c𝑐c be the constant from Lemma 1. We take k=⌊c​(r/m)β⌋𝑘𝑐superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽k=\lfloor c(r/m)^{\beta}\rfloor in (11) and assume that r/m𝑟𝑚r/m is large enough to ensure that (r/m)​e−η​k≤1/8𝑟𝑚superscript𝑒𝜂𝑘18(r/m)e^{-\eta k}\leq 1/8. Using Lemma 1 and intersecting with the event in (11) we deduce by (10) that

ℙ​(𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁​(𝒢r)<m3∧k⋅f​(2​m)4)ℙ𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁subscript𝒢𝑟𝑚3⋅𝑘𝑓2𝑚4\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\mathsf{Width}(\mathcal{G}_{r})<\frac{m}{3}\wedge\frac{k\cdot f(2m)}{4}\right) ≤\displaystyle\leq ℙ​(min0≤ℓ≤(r/m)−2⁡Nr​(2​m,ℓ​m)<c​(rm)β)+(r/m)​e−η​kℙsubscript0ℓ𝑟𝑚2subscript𝑁𝑟2𝑚ℓ𝑚𝑐superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽𝑟𝑚superscript𝑒𝜂𝑘\displaystyle\mathbb{P}\left(\min_{0\leq\ell\leq(r/m)-2}N_{r}(2m,\ell m)<c\left(\frac{r}{m}\right)^{\beta}\right)+(r/m)e^{-\eta k}
≤\displaystyle\leq 18+18=14.181814\displaystyle\frac{1}{8}+\frac{1}{8}=\frac{1}{4}.

By definition of f​(r)𝑓𝑟f(r) we thus deduce that

2.2 The dual width

In order to analyze resistances, it is more convenient to have control of the width of the dual of a block than of the block itself. Given r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1 and a block 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, we define the dual width of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, denoted 𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁†​(𝒢r)superscript𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁†subscript𝒢𝑟\mathsf{Width}^{\dagger}(\mathcal{G}_{r}), to be length of the shortest path in the planar dual of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} that starts and ends in the outside face, has its first and last edges in the left and right-hand boundaries of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} respectively, and which does not visit the outside face other than at its endpoints. We call such a path a dual left-right crossing of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}.

We claim that the dual width of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} is equal to the maximal size of a set of edge-disjoint (primal) paths from the bottom to the top of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r} (we call such a path a primal bottom-top crossing), whence its close connection to resistances. One such maximal set of primal bottom-top crossings can be found algorithmically by first taking the left-most primal bottom-top crossing, then the left-most primal bottom-top crossing that is edge-disjoint from the first one, and so on. The claim can be proved using the cut-cycle duality [19, Theorem 14.3.1] and Menger’s theorem, but can also easily be checked in our situation, see Figure 6 below.

For each r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, we define g​(r)𝑔𝑟g(r) to be the median dual width of 𝒢rsubscript𝒢𝑟\mathcal{G}_{r}, that is, the largest number such that

ℙ​(𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁†​(𝒢r)≥g​(r))≥1/2.ℙsuperscript𝖶𝗂𝖽𝗍𝗁†subscript𝒢𝑟𝑔𝑟12\mathbb{P}\big{(}\mathsf{Width}^{\dagger}(\mathcal{G}_{r})\geq g(r)\big{)}\geq 1/2.

The proof of Theorem 1 goes through essentially unchanged to yield that there exists a constant c>0𝑐0c>0 such that

g​(r)≥c⋅min⁡{m;(r/m)β​g​(m)}∀1≤m≤c⋅r,formulae-sequence𝑔𝑟⋅𝑐𝑚superscript𝑟𝑚𝛽𝑔𝑚for-all1𝑚⋅𝑐𝑟\displaystyle g(r)\geq c\cdot\min\Big{\{}m;(r/m)^{\beta}g(m)\Big{\}}\qquad\forall 1\leq m\leq c\cdot r,

from which we obtain as before the following analogue of Theorem 5.

Theorem 6 (g​(r)𝑔𝑟g(r) is almost linear).

If μ𝜇\mu is critical and satisfies (1) then there exists c>0𝑐0c>0 such that for all r𝑟r large enough we have

g​(r)≥c​r.𝑔𝑟𝑐𝑟g(r)\geq c\,r.

On the other hand, if μ𝜇\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance then there exists C>0𝐶0C>0 such that for all r𝑟r large enough we have

g​(r)≥r​exp⁡(−C​log⁡r).𝑔𝑟𝑟𝐶𝑟g(r)\geq r\exp(-C\sqrt{\log r}).

2.3 The subadditive argument

In this section we suppose that μ𝜇\mu is critical and has finite variance. We use the same notation as in the preceding section. In particular, we let 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q_{\infty}} be the quarter-plane model, as defined in Section 2.1, and recall that 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty} is indexed by {1,2,…}×{0,1,…}12…01…\{1,2,\ldots\}\times\{0,1,\ldots\}. For each m≥n≥1𝑚𝑛1m\geq n\geq 1 let 𝒬n,msubscript𝒬𝑛𝑚\mathcal{Q}_{n,m} be the subgraph of 𝒬∞subscript𝒬\mathcal{Q}_{\infty} induced by the trees Tn,…,Tmsubscript𝑇𝑛…subscript𝑇𝑚T_{n},\ldots,T_{m}, and let Ln,msubscript𝐿𝑛𝑚L_{n,m} be the graph distance between (n,0)𝑛0(n,0) and (m,0)𝑚0(m,0) in 𝒬n,msubscript𝒬𝑛𝑚\mathcal{Q}_{n,m}. Our aim is to prove the following.

Proposition 2.

If μ𝜇\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance then limn→∞1n​L1,n=0subscript→𝑛1𝑛subscript𝐿1𝑛0\lim_{n\to\infty}\frac{1}{n}L_{1,n}=0 a.s.

Proof.

The proof is based on a simple observation together with Kingman’s subadditive ergodic theorem. We clearly have that the random array (Ln,m)m≥n≥1subscriptsubscript𝐿𝑛𝑚𝑚𝑛1(L_{n,m})_{m\geq n\geq 1} is stationary in the sense that (Ln+k,m+k)m≥n≥1subscriptsubscript𝐿𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑛1(L_{n+k,m+k})_{m\geq n\geq 1} has the same distribution as (Ln,m)m≥n≥1subscriptsubscript𝐿𝑛𝑚𝑚𝑛1(L_{n,m})_{m\geq n\geq 1} for every m≥n≥1𝑚𝑛1m\geq n\geq 1 and k≥1𝑘1k\geq 1, and is subadditive in the sense that Ln,m+k≤Ln,m+Lm,m+ksubscript𝐿𝑛𝑚𝑘subscript𝐿𝑛𝑚subscript𝐿𝑚𝑚𝑘L_{n,m+k}\leq L_{n,m}+L_{m,m+k} for every n,m,k≥1𝑛𝑚𝑘1n,m,k\geq 1. Moreover, since the Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i}’s are i.i.d., the stationary sequence ((Ln+k,m+k)m≥n≥1)k≥0subscriptsubscriptsubscript𝐿𝑛𝑘𝑚𝑘𝑚𝑛1𝑘0((L_{n+k,m+k})_{m\geq n\geq 1})_{k\geq 0} is ergodic and we can apply Kingman’s subadditive ergodic theorem to deduce that

n−1​L1,n→n→∞a.s.c,\displaystyle n^{-1}L_{1,n}\xrightarrow[n\to\infty]{a.s.}c, (16)

for some non-random constant c∈[0,1]𝑐01c\in[0,1].

To finish the proof and show that c=0𝑐0c=0, we use the following observation. Recall that for r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, we denoted by ξr=:ξr(1)\xi_{r}=:\xi_{r}^{(1)} the index of the first tree among T1,T2,…subscript𝑇1subscript𝑇2…T_{1},T_{2},\dots that reaches height r𝑟r. We also denote by ξr(2)subscriptsuperscript𝜉2𝑟\xi^{{(2)}}_{r} the index of the second such tree. Considering the path that starts at (1,0)10(1,0), travels horizontally to (ξr(1),0)superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟10(\xi_{r}^{(1)},0), travels vertically up to the right-most element of Tξr(1)subscript𝑇superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟1T_{\xi_{r}^{(1)}} in level r𝑟r, takes one step to the right, and then travels vertically downwards to (ξr(2),0)superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟20(\xi_{r}^{(2)},0), as illustrated in Figure 7, yields the bound

L1,ξr(2)≤ξr(1)+2​r.subscript𝐿1subscriptsuperscript𝜉2𝑟superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟12𝑟\displaystyle L_{1,\xi^{(2)}_{r}}\leq\xi_{r}^{(1)}+2r. (17)

Using (3), it is easy to show that r−1​ξr(1)superscript𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟1r^{-1}\xi_{r}^{(1)} and r−1​(ξr(2)−ξr(1))superscript𝑟1superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟2superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟1r^{-1}(\xi_{r}^{(2)}-\xi_{r}^{(1)}) converge in distribution towards a pair of independent exponential random variables with the same parameter. In particular, it follows that

lim infr→∞ℙ​(ξr(1)+2​r≤ε⋅ξr(2))>0subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑟ℙsuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟12𝑟⋅𝜀superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑟20\liminf_{r\to\infty}\mathbb{P}\bigl{(}\xi_{r}^{(1)}+2r\leq\varepsilon\cdot\xi_{r}^{(2)}\bigr{)}>0

for every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. This observation together with the a.s. convergence (16) and the bound (17) yields that c≤ε𝑐𝜀c\leq\varepsilon. Since this inequality is valid for every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 we must have that c=0𝑐0c=0. ∎

3 Estimating the girth

In this section we will derive our Theorems 1 and 4 from the estimates on the geometry of blocks derived in the last section. In order to do this, we relate the μ𝜇\mu-Galton–Watson tree conditioned to survive T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} (and the graph 𝒞∞=𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)subscript𝒞𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathscr{C}_{\infty}=\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) obtained by adding the horizontal edges to T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} as in Figure 2) to the unconditioned quarter-plane model made of i.i.d. μ𝜇\mu-Galton–Watson trees that we considered in Section 2. The main ingredient is the standard representation of T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} using the spine decomposition [29], which we now review. We refer to [1] for precise statements and proofs regarding this decomposition.

The plane tree T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} has a unique spine (an infinite line of descent) which can be seen as the genealogy of a mutant particle which reproduces according to the biased distribution μ¯=(k⋅μk)k≥0¯𝜇subscript⋅𝑘subscript𝜇𝑘𝑘0\overline{\mu}=(k\cdot\mu_{k})_{k\geq 0} and from which exactly one of its offspring is chosen at random and declared mutant. All other particles reproduce according to the underlying offspring distribution μ𝜇\mu, see Figure 8 (left) and [1] for more details. We deduce from this representation that, for every n0≥1subscript𝑛01n_{0}\geq 1, conditionally on #​∂[T∞]n0#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇subscript𝑛0\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n_{0}}, if at generation n0subscript𝑛0n_{0} we erase the only mutant particle and all its offspring then we obtain a forest of (#​∂[T∞]n0−1)#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇subscript𝑛01(\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n_{0}}-1) independent μ𝜇\mu-Galton–Watson trees. We order the trees in this forest using the plane ordering of T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} so that the first tree is the one immediately to the right of the spine and the last tree is the one immediately to the left of the spine. Denote this forest by ℱn0subscriptℱsubscript𝑛0\mathcal{F}_{n_{0}} and note that it can be empty. We add the horizontal connections between inner vertices of ℱn0subscriptℱsubscript𝑛0\mathcal{F}_{n_{0}} (except those linking the extreme vertices of a line) to get the graph 𝒞n0subscript𝒞subscript𝑛0\mathcal{C}_{n_{0}} which is then a subgraph of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. The graph 𝒞n0subscript𝒞subscript𝑛0\mathcal{C}_{n_{0}} truncated at height k𝑘k will be denoted by [𝒞n0]ksubscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝒞subscript𝑛0𝑘[\mathcal{C}_{n_{0}}]_{k}. See Figure 8.

It is also standard that T∞subscript𝑇T_{\infty} is the martingale biasing of the random variable T𝑇T by the non-negative martingale (#​∂[T]n)n≥0subscript#subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝑛𝑛0(\#\partial[T]_{n})_{n\geq 0}. That is, for every positive function f𝑓f on the set of finite plane trees we have

𝔼​[f​([T∞]n)]=𝔼​[f​([T]n)​#​∂[T]n]𝔼delimited-[]𝑓subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑛𝔼delimited-[]𝑓subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝑛#subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝑛\mathbb{E}[f([T_{\infty}]_{n})]=\mathbb{E}[f([T]_{n})\#\partial[T]_{n}]

for every n≥0𝑛0n\geq 0. In particular the size of the n𝑛n-th generation #​∂[T∞]n#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑛\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n} has the law of #​∂[T]n#subscriptdelimited-[]𝑇𝑛\#\partial[T]_{n} biased by itself. It is also standard (see [31, Theorem 4]) that #​∂[T∞]n#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑛\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n} is of order nβsuperscript𝑛𝛽n^{\beta} (recall the definition of β𝛽\beta at the end of the Introduction) and more precisely that once rescaled by n−βsuperscript𝑛𝛽n^{-\beta} it converges in distribution towards a positive random variable:

n−β​#​∂[T∞]n→n→∞𝑑𝒳′>0.superscript𝑛𝛽#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑛→𝑛𝑑→superscript𝒳′0\displaystyle n^{-\beta}\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n}\quad\xrightarrow[n\to\infty]{d}\quad\mathcal{X}^{\prime}>0. (18)

Here again, the precise distribution of the random variable 𝒳′superscript𝒳′\mathcal{X}^{\prime} will not be used. We shall however use a version of this estimate which is rougher for a given n𝑛n but holds simultaneously for all n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1:

A straightforward corollary of Lemma 3 concerns the volume growth from the origin (as alluded to in the introduction): If Brsubscript𝐵𝑟B_{r} denotes the graph ball of radius r𝑟r around in origin in 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} and #​Br#subscript𝐵𝑟\#B_{r} the number of vertices of Brsubscript𝐵𝑟B_{r} then

rβ+1​(log⁡r)−C≤#​Br≤rβ+1​(log⁡r)Csuperscript𝑟𝛽1superscript𝑟𝐶#subscript𝐵𝑟superscript𝑟𝛽1superscript𝑟𝐶\displaystyle r^{\beta+1}\big{(}\log r\big{)}^{-C}\leq\#B_{r}\leq r^{\beta+1}\big{(}\log r\big{)}^{C} (21)

for all sufficiently large r𝑟r almost surely. See [9, Proposition 2.8] and [11, Lemma 5.1] for more precise estimates. We now have all the ingredients to complete the proof of our Theorems 1 and 4. In fact, we will prove the following quantitative version of item (i)𝑖(i) of Theorem 1.

Proposition 3 (Quantitative girth lower bound for generic causal maps).

Suppose μ𝜇\mu is critical and has finite non-zero variance. Then there exists a constant C𝐶C such that

1r​𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁r​(𝒞∞)≥e−C​log⁡r1𝑟subscript𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁𝑟subscript𝒞superscript𝑒𝐶𝑟\frac{1}{r}\mathsf{Girth}_{r}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\geq e^{-C\sqrt{\log r}}

almost surely for all r𝑟r sufficiently large.

Proof of Theorem 1 (i), Theorem 4 (i), and Proposition 3.

Fix ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0. Pick n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 large and consider the forest ℱnsubscriptℱ𝑛\mathcal{F}_{n} introduced above. This forest is obviously finite.

By (3) and (8), conditionally on the event that #​∂[T∞]n≥nβ​(log⁡n)−C1#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑛superscript𝑛𝛽superscript𝑛subscript𝐶1\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n}\geq n^{\beta}(\log n)^{-C_{1}}, the probability that there are at least (log⁡n)2superscript𝑛2(\log n)^{2} trees inside this forest which reach height at least m=m​(n)=n​(log⁡n)−(3+C1)β𝑚𝑚𝑛𝑛superscript𝑛3subscript𝐶1𝛽m=m(n)=n(\log n)^{-{(3+C_{1})\over\beta}} (relative to their starting height of n𝑛n) is lower bounded by

The second part of Theorem 4 follows the same lines. Let us sketch the argument.

Finally, we prove the upper bound on the girth in the finite-variance case.

Proof of Theorem 1 (ii).

We fix μ𝜇\mu critical and having a finite, non-zero variance. Fix n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 large and consider the graph 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n}, which is a subgraph of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. As before, conditional on #​∂[T∞]n=ℓ#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑛ℓ\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{n}=\ell this graph is made of ℓ−1ℓ1\ell-1 i.i.d. Galton–Watson trees together with the added horizontal connections. Proposition 2 directly tells us that the distance inside 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} between its bottom-left corner x𝑥x and its bottom-right corner y𝑦y is o​(ℓ)𝑜ℓo(\ell) with high probability.

Since x𝑥x and y𝑦y are both incident to the spine vertex at level n𝑛n, we can use two horizontal edges to link x𝑥x to y𝑦y in 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} as depicted on the right. Since ℓ=O​(n)ℓ𝑂𝑛\ell=O(n) with high probability by (18), this argument shows that for each ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 there exists N<∞𝑁N<\infty such that if n≥N𝑛𝑁n\geq N then we can construct, with probability at least 1−ε1𝜀1-\varepsilon, a loop ℒℒ\mathcal{L} inside 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} of length at most ε​n𝜀𝑛\varepsilon n that separates ρ𝜌\rho from ∞\infty and that only contains vertices of height between n𝑛n and (1+ε)​n1𝜀𝑛(1+\varepsilon)n.

Let n≥N𝑛𝑁n\geq N, condition on this event, and consider the set of vertices of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} at height n′=n+⌈ε​n⌉superscript𝑛′𝑛𝜀𝑛n^{\prime}=n+\lceil\varepsilon n\rceil. Each such vertex is connected to a vertex at height n𝑛n by a path of length ⌈ε​n⌉𝜀𝑛\lceil\varepsilon n\rceil, and this path must intersect ℒℒ\mathcal{L}. We deduce that the distance between any vertex of [T∞]n′subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇superscript𝑛′[T_{\infty}]_{n^{\prime}} and ℒℒ\mathcal{L} is less than ε​n𝜀𝑛\varepsilon n. We deduce that 𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁n′​(T∞)≤3​ε​nsubscript𝖦𝗂𝗋𝗍𝗁superscript𝑛′subscript𝑇3𝜀𝑛\mathsf{Girth}_{n^{\prime}}(T_{\infty})\leq 3\varepsilon n with probability at least 1−ε1𝜀1-\varepsilon for every n≥N𝑛𝑁n\geq N, from which the proof may easily be concluded. ∎

4 Resistance growth and spectral dimension

In this section we will prove Theorem 2, via Theorem 3. Since certain arguments are valid in general, we highlight when finite variance is needed.

4.1 Resistance

The resistance will be controlled through the method of random paths and builds upon the geometric estimates established in the preceding section. In this section, all resistances will be taken with respect to the graph 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. Before diving into the proof of Theorem 3, we first prove that 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} is recurrent (i.e., that 𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔Brc)=𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔∂[T∞]r+1;𝒞∞)→∞\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})=\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r+1};\mathscr{C}_{\infty})\to\infty as r→∞→𝑟r\to\infty).

Proposition 4.

If μ𝜇\mu has finite non-zero variance then 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} is recurrent almost surely.

Proof.

We apply the Nash–Williams criterion for recurrence [30, (2.14)], using the obvious collection of cut-sets given by the sets of edges linking level r𝑟r to level r+1𝑟1r+1 for each r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1. This edge set has cardinality precisely #​∂[T∞]r+1#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑟1\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r+1} so the proposition reduces to checking that

∑r=1∞1#​∂[T∞]r=∞, almost surely.superscriptsubscript𝑟11#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑟 almost surely\sum_{r=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}}=\infty,\quad\mbox{ almost surely}.

Since we have that 1#​∂[T∞]r=1r​r#​∂[T∞]r1#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑟1𝑟𝑟#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑟\frac{1}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}}=\frac{1}{r}\frac{r}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}} and by (18) that the random variable r#​∂[T∞]r𝑟#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑟\frac{r}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{r}} converges in law towards a positive random variable, the last display is a direct consequence of Jeulin’s Lemma [22, Proposition 4 c]. ∎

Remark.

Let us briefly discuss quantitative resistance lower bounds. It follows immediately from Nash-Williams that

𝔼[𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔Brc)]≥∑k=1r1k𝔼[k#​∂[T∞]k]≥clogr\mathbb{E}\left[\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})\right]\geq\sum_{k=1}^{r}\frac{1}{k}\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{k}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{k}}\right]\geq c\log r

for some c>0𝑐0c>0 by (18). With a little further effort one can prove an almost sure lower bound on the resistance growth of the form

𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔Brc)≥∑k=1r1#​∂[T∞]k≥clogr for all n sufficiently large a.s.\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})\geq\sum_{k=1}^{r}\frac{1}{\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{k}}\geq c\log r\qquad\text{ for all $n$ sufficiently large a.s.}

Indeed, in the analogous statement for the CSBP the contributions from successive dyadic scales form a stationary ergodic sequence and the result follows from the ergodic theorem. Pushing this argument through to the discrete case requires one to handle some straightforward but tedious technical details. We do not pursue this further here.

Note that the number of edges at height ℓℓ\ell is equal to #​∂[T∞]ℓ+#​∂[T∞]ℓ+1#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇ℓ#subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇ℓ1\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{\ell}+\#\partial[T_{\infty}]_{\ell+1}, and hence is at most O​(ℓ​logC1⁡ℓ)𝑂ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝐶1ℓO(\ell\log^{C_{1}}\ell) on the event ΩΩ\Omega. On the other hand, the initial segment of ΓΓ\Gamma reaching from ρ𝜌\rho to level hn0subscriptℎsubscript𝑛0h_{n_{0}} increases the energy of ΓΓ\Gamma by at most a constant. Thus, we have that

𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔Bhnc)≤O(1)+∑ℓ=hn0hn[ℓ−1eC5​log⁡ℓ]2O(ℓlogC1ℓ)≤eC6​log⁡hn,\mathsf{R_{eff}}\bigl{(}\rho\leftrightarrow B^{c}_{h_{n}}\bigr{)}\leq O(1)+\sum_{\ell=h_{n_{0}}}^{h_{n}}\left[\ell^{-1}e^{C_{5}\sqrt{\log\ell}}\right]^{2}O(\ell\log^{C_{1}}\ell)\leq e^{C_{6}\sqrt{\log h_{n}}}\,,

for some constant C6>0subscript𝐶60C_{6}>0, as claimed. ∎

Remark.

One can adapt the proof of Theorem 2 to the α𝛼\alpha-stable case. Following the same construction of the random path as in the above proof and applying Lemma 3 with the appropriate β>1𝛽1\beta>1 we now deduce that the energy of the path ΓΓ\Gamma linking ρ𝜌\rho to Brcsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑟𝑐B_{r}^{c} is of order

𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔Brc)≤∑h=1rh−2hβ(logh)C1≤rβ−1(logr)C2\mathsf{R_{eff}}(\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c})\leq\sum_{h=1}^{r}h^{-2}h^{\beta}\big{(}\log h\big{)}^{C_{1}}\leq r^{\beta-1}\big{(}\log r\big{)}^{C_{2}}

for some C1,C2>0subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶20C_{1},C_{2}>0 as r→∞→𝑟r\to\infty. In particular, the resistance exponent 𝔯𝔯\mathfrak{r} (if it is well-defined) satisfies 𝔯≤β−1=2−αα−1𝔯𝛽12𝛼𝛼1\mathfrak{r}\leq\beta-1=\frac{2-\alpha}{\alpha-1}. However, this bound on the resistance becomes trivial in the regime α∈(1;3/2]𝛼132\alpha\in(1;3/2] since then β≥2𝛽2\beta\geq 2 and we obtain a super-linear upper bound on the resistance… which is trivially at most r𝑟r!

4.2 Spectral dimension and diffusivity (Theorem 2)

We can now prove Theorem 2.

Proof of Theorem 2.

We denote by Pn​(x,y)superscript𝑃𝑛𝑥𝑦P^{n}(x,y) the n𝑛n-step transition probabilities of the simple random walk (Xn)n≥0subscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛𝑛0(X_{n})_{n\geq 0} on the graph 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. Recall that P𝒞∞,ρsubscriptPsubscript𝒞𝜌\mathrm{P}_{\mathscr{C}_{\infty},\rho} is the law of the random walk on 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} started from ρ𝜌\rho and recall also that Brsubscript𝐵𝑟B_{r} denote the ball of radius r𝑟r around the origin vertex ρ∈𝒞∞𝜌subscript𝒞\rho\in\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. We will split the proof of Theorem 2 into lower and upper bounds for return probabilities and typical displacements. As we will see, the upper bound for the return probability is a simple consequence of our resistance estimates (Theorem 3) while the upper bound on the typical displacement is a standard application of the Varopoulos–Carne heat kernel bound for polynomially growing graph. Let us proceed.

(Return probability upper bound.) Recall that deg(ρ)𝖱𝖾𝖿𝖿(ρ↔Brc)\deg(\rho)\mathsf{R_{eff}}\bigl{(}\rho\leftrightarrow B_{r}^{c}\bigr{)} is equal to the expected number of times that the random walk started at ρ𝜌\rho visits ρ𝜌\rho before first leaving Brsubscript𝐵𝑟B_{r}. By the spectral decomposition for reversible Markov chains (see [28, Lemma 12.2]) we know that P2​n​(x,x)superscript𝑃2𝑛𝑥𝑥P^{2n}(x,x) is a decreasing function of n𝑛n for every vertex x𝑥x of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. Hence letting τrsubscript𝜏𝑟\tau_{r} be the first time that the random walk visits Brcsuperscriptsubscript𝐵𝑟𝑐B_{r}^{c}, we have the bound

(n+1)P2​n(ρ,ρ)≤∑m=0nP2​m(ρ,ρ)≤𝐄𝒞∞,ρ[∑m=0τ2​n1(Xm=ρ)]=deg(ρ)Reff(ρ↔B2​nc).(n+1)P^{2n}(\rho,\rho)\leq\sum_{m=0}^{n}P^{2m}(\rho,\rho)\leq\mathbf{E}_{\mathscr{C}_{\infty},\rho}\left[\sum_{m=0}^{\tau_{2n}}{1}\bigl{(}X_{m}=\rho\bigr{)}\right]=\deg(\rho)R_{\rm eff}\bigl{(}\rho\leftrightarrow B_{2n}^{c}\bigr{)}.

Thus, applying Theorem 3 yields that

P2​n​(ρ,ρ)≤n−1​eC​log⁡nsuperscript𝑃2𝑛𝜌𝜌superscript𝑛1superscript𝑒𝐶𝑛P^{2n}(\rho,\rho)\leq n^{-1}e^{C\sqrt{\log n}} (23)

for all sufficiently large n𝑛n almost surely.

To obtain a similar bound for odd n𝑛n, we use the well-known fact that return probabilities are log-convex in the sense that Pn+m​(ρ,ρ)≤P2​n​(ρ,ρ)​P2​m​(ρ,ρ)superscript𝑃𝑛𝑚𝜌𝜌superscript𝑃2𝑛𝜌𝜌superscript𝑃2𝑚𝜌𝜌P^{n+m}(\rho,\rho)\leq\sqrt{P^{2n}(\rho,\rho)P^{2m}(\rho,\rho)} for every n,m≥0𝑛𝑚0n,m\geq 0 [3, Lemma 3.20]: Applying this fact together with (23) we obtain that

Pn​(ρ,ρ)≤P2​⌊n/2⌋​(ρ,ρ)​P2​⌈n/2⌉​(ρ,ρ)≤2​n−1​eC​log⁡nsuperscript𝑃𝑛𝜌𝜌superscript𝑃2𝑛2𝜌𝜌superscript𝑃2𝑛2𝜌𝜌2superscript𝑛1superscript𝑒𝐶𝑛P^{n}(\rho,\rho)\leq\sqrt{P^{2\lfloor n/2\rfloor}(\rho,\rho)P^{2\lceil n/2\rceil}(\rho,\rho)}\leq 2n^{-1}e^{C\sqrt{\log n}} (24)

for all sufficiently large n𝑛n almost surely.

(Typical displacement upper bound.) Recall the classical Varopulous-Carne bound [30, Section 13.2], which implies that for every vertex x𝑥x of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} and every n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 we have that

Pn​(ρ,x)≤2​deg⁡(x)deg⁡(ρ)​exp⁡[−12​n​dgr𝒞∞​(ρ,x)2]≤2​deg⁡(x)​exp⁡[−12​n​dgr𝒞∞​(ρ,x)2].superscript𝑃𝑛𝜌𝑥2degree𝑥degree𝜌12𝑛subscriptsuperscriptdsubscript𝒞grsuperscript𝜌𝑥22degree𝑥12𝑛subscriptsuperscriptdsubscript𝒞grsuperscript𝜌𝑥2P^{n}(\rho,x)\leq 2\sqrt{\frac{\deg(x)}{\deg(\rho)}}\exp\left[-\frac{1}{2n}\mathrm{d}^{\mathscr{C}_{\infty}}_{\mathrm{gr}}(\rho,x)^{2}\right]\leq 2\deg(x)\exp\left[-\frac{1}{2n}\mathrm{d}^{\mathscr{C}_{\infty}}_{\mathrm{gr}}(\rho,x)^{2}\right].

Observe that, since every vertex of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty} at height n≥1𝑛1n\geq 1 has at most three edges emanating from it that connect to vertices at height less than or equal to n𝑛n, we have that ∑x∈Bndeg⁡(x)≤4⋅#​Bn+1subscript𝑥subscript𝐵𝑛degree𝑥⋅4#subscript𝐵𝑛1\sum_{x\in B_{n}}\deg(x)\leq 4\cdot\#B_{n+1}. Thus, it follows from (21) that there exists a constant C𝐶C such that ∑x∈Bndeg⁡(x)≤n2​(log⁡n)Csubscript𝑥subscript𝐵𝑛degree𝑥superscript𝑛2superscript𝑛𝐶\sum_{x\in B_{n}}\deg(x)\leq n^{2}\big{(}\log n\big{)}^{C} for all sufficiently large n𝑛n almost surely. By the last display ∑nP𝒞∞,ρ​(Xn∉B5​n​log⁡n)<∞subscript𝑛subscriptPsubscript𝒞𝜌subscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝐵5𝑛𝑛\sum_{n}\mathrm{P}_{\mathscr{C}_{\infty},\rho}(X_{n}\notin B_{\sqrt{5n\log n}})<\infty for almost all realizations of 𝒞∞subscript𝒞\mathscr{C}_{\infty}. It follows by Borel–Cantelli (under P𝒞∞,ρsubscriptPsubscript𝒞𝜌\mathrm{P}_{\mathscr{C}_{\infty},\rho}) that

lim supn→∞dgr𝒞∞​(ρ,Xn)n​log⁡n≤5subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛subscriptsuperscriptdsubscript𝒞gr𝜌subscript𝑋𝑛𝑛𝑛5\limsup_{n\to\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}^{\mathscr{C}_{\infty}}_{\mathrm{gr}}(\rho,X_{n})}{\sqrt{n\log n}}\leq\sqrt{5} (25)

almost surely. This gives one side of the claim that ν=1/2𝜈12\nu=1/2.

(Return probability lower bound.) To get a lower bound on Pn​(ρ,ρ)superscript𝑃𝑛𝜌𝜌P^{n}(\rho,\rho), first observe that

P2​n​(ρ,ρ)=∑x∈VPn​(ρ,x)​Pn​(x,ρ)=∑x∈Vdeg⁡(ρ)deg⁡(x)​Pn​(ρ,x)2.superscript𝑃2𝑛𝜌𝜌subscript𝑥𝑉superscript𝑃𝑛𝜌𝑥superscript𝑃𝑛𝑥𝜌subscript𝑥𝑉degree𝜌degree𝑥superscript𝑃𝑛superscript𝜌𝑥2\displaystyle P^{2n}(\rho,\rho)=\sum_{x\in V}P^{n}(\rho,x)P^{n}(x,\rho)=\sum_{x\in V}\frac{\deg(\rho)}{\deg(x)}P^{n}(\rho,x)^{2}.

It follows that, for every r≥0𝑟0r\geq 0,

P2​n​(ρ,ρ)≥∑x∈Brdeg⁡(ρ)deg⁡(x)​Pn​(ρ,x)2≥deg⁡(ρ)​𝐏𝒞∞,ρ​(Xn∈Br)2​1∑x∈Brdeg⁡(x)superscript𝑃2𝑛𝜌𝜌subscript𝑥subscript𝐵𝑟degree𝜌degree𝑥superscript𝑃𝑛superscript𝜌𝑥2degree𝜌subscript𝐏subscript𝒞𝜌superscriptsubscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝐵𝑟21subscript𝑥subscript𝐵𝑟degree𝑥\displaystyle P^{2n}(\rho,\rho)\geq\sum_{x\in B_{r}}\frac{\deg(\rho)}{\deg(x)}P^{n}(\rho,x)^{2}\geq\deg(\rho)\mathbf{P}_{\mathscr{C}_{\infty},\rho}\bigl{(}X_{n}\in B_{r}\bigr{)}^{2}\frac{1}{\sum_{x\in B_{r}}\deg(x)} (26)

where the second inequality follows by Cauchy–Schwarz. Taking r=⌊5​n​log⁡n⌋𝑟5𝑛𝑛r=\lfloor\sqrt{5n\log n}\rfloor we deduce by (21) and the above application of Varopoulos–Carne that there exists a constant positive C𝐶C such that

almost surely as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty. Together with (23) this implies that ds​(𝒞∞)subscript𝑑𝑠subscript𝒞d_{s}(\mathscr{C}_{\infty}) exists and equals 222 a.s.

(Typical displacement lower bound.) for every ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 a.s. Together with (25) this implies that ν​(𝒞∞)𝜈subscript𝒞\nu(\mathscr{C}_{\infty}) exists and equals 1/2121/2 a.s. ∎

5 Extensions and comments

5.1 Back to Causal Triangulations

Definition 2.

A causal triangulation is a finite rooted triangulation of the sphere such that the maximal distance to the origin of the map is attained by a single vertex, and for each k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 the subgraph induced by the set of vertices at distance k≥0𝑘0k\geq 0 from the origin is a cycle.

In this work, we focused on the model 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(τ)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅𝜏\mathsf{Causal}(\tau) which is obtained from a plane tree τ𝜏\tau by adding the horizontal connections between vertices are the same generation. As explained in Figure 2, to get a causal triangulation one needs also to triangulate the faces from their top right corners. (Furthermore, one must add a point at the top of the graph to triangulate the top most face, even if this face is already a triangle). As explained in [17] this construction is a bijection between the set of finite rooted plane trees and the set of finite causal triangulations.

When this procedure is applied to the uniform infinite random tree 𝕋∞subscript𝕋\mathbb{T}_{\infty} (which is distributed as a critical geometric Galton-Watson tree conditioned to survive forever) the resulting map 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂​(𝕋∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂subscript𝕋\mathsf{CauTri}(\mathbb{T}_{\infty}) is the uniform infinite causal triangulation (UICT) as considered in [17, 32]. The large scale geometries of 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂subscript𝑇\mathsf{CauTri}({T}_{\infty}) and 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathsf{Causal}({T}_{\infty}) are very similar and it is easy to adapt the results of the present paper to this setting.

Moreover, while it is certainly possible to simply run our arguments again to analyze 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀subscript𝑇\mathsf{CauTrig}(T_{\infty}) instead of 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}), it is also possible to simply deduce versions of each of our main theorems concerning 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂subscript𝑇\mathsf{CauTri}(T_{\infty}) from the statements that we give. Indeed, using the fact that the largest face in the first n𝑛n levels of 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) is at most logarithmically large in n𝑛n yields that distances within the first n𝑛n levels of 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂𝗀subscript𝑇\mathsf{CauTrig}(T_{\infty}) are smaller than those in 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) by at most a logarithmic factor. Moreover, an analogue of the resistance upper bound of Theorem 3 follows immediately since 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝗌𝖺𝗅subscript𝑇\mathsf{Causal}(T_{\infty}) is a subgraph of 𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂​(T∞)𝖢𝖺𝗎𝖳𝗋𝗂subscript𝑇\mathsf{CauTri}(T_{\infty}).

We let the reader stare at the two beautiful pictures in Figure 10.

5.2 Causal carpets

Finally, we want to stress that our results can be adapted to various other graphs obtained from trees by “adding the horizontal connections”. For example one could decide, when transforming a plane tree τ𝜏\tau to add the horizontal connections but only keeping the extreme most edges of each branch point, see Figure 11.

We call this graph the causal carpet associated to the tree. The geometry of the α𝛼\alpha-stable causal carpet is very different from the maps studied in this work, since the faces of this map may now have very large degree. In spite of this, the block-renormalisation methodology developed in Section 2 carries through to this model, and analogs of Theorem 4, as well as of the resistance exponent bound

𝔯≤2−αα−1𝔯2𝛼𝛼1\mathfrak{r}\leq\frac{2-\alpha}{\alpha-1}

hold true. Alas, this resistance bound becomes trivial precisely at the most interesting value of α=3/2𝛼32\alpha=3/2, for which a graph closely related to the causal carpet can be realized as a subgraph of the UIPT via Krikun’s skeleton decomposition or via the recent construction of [12]. Indeed, it remains open to prove any sublinear resistance upper bound for the UIPT. Such a bound would (morally) follow from the α=3/2𝛼32\alpha=3/2 case of the following conjecture.

Conjecture 1.

Let μ𝜇\mu be critical and satisfy (1) for some α∈(1,2)𝛼12\alpha\in(1,2). Then the resistance growth exponent 𝔯𝔯\mathfrak{r} of the associated causal carpet exists and satisfies 0<𝔯<10𝔯10<\mathfrak{r}<1 almost surely. In particular, the causal carpet is recurrent almost surely.

Despite the sub-optimality of our spectral results in this context, the geometric results obtained by our methods are sharp. The applications of our methodology to uniform random planar triangulations will be explored further in a future work.

Finally, we remark that a model essentially equivalent to the uniform CDT arises as a certain γ↓0↓𝛾0\gamma\downarrow 0 limit of Liouville Quantum Gravity (LQG) in the mating-of-trees framework [14, 20]. (More specifically, it arises as the γ↓0↓𝛾0\gamma\downarrow 0 limit of the mated-Galton-Watson-tree model of LQG, in which the correlation of the encoding random walks tends to −11-1). Thus, further study of the uniform CDT may prove useful for understanding LQG in the small γ𝛾\gamma regime, which has recently been of great interest following Ding and Goswami’s refutation of the Watabiki formula [13].

Added in proof. Gwynne and Miller [21] recently proved sub-polynomial resistance estimates for the UIPT. Conjecture 1 and the analogous question for the skeleton of the UIPT remain open, however.
